item.title: Pfizer Asks F.D.A. to Authorize Its Covid-19 Vaccine for Children 5 to 11
item.description: The agency has promised to move quickly on the request and has tentatively scheduled a meeting at the end of the month to consider it.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
item.media:description: A 9-year-old receiving a second dose of Pfizer�s coronavirus vaccine in a clinical trial for children in Durham, N.C., in April.

item.title: How a Vaccine Mandate Could Worsen a Shortage of Home Care Aides
item.description: Some 250,000 home health care workers must get the coronavirus vaccine by Friday, but tens of thousands of them have yet to receive it.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman
item.media:description: Many industry officials fear the mandate will result in thousands of workers simply quitting their jobs and finding new work in restaurants, retail or other industries.

item.title: Senate Leaders Agree to Short-Term Debt Ceiling Increase
item.description: The agreement avoids catastrophic consequences of a default by the federal government, but runs only through early December.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer announced Thursday morning that he had reached an agreement with Senator Mitch McConnell to clear the way for a vote on a short-term extension.

item.title: Taxing the Rich
item.description: Americans strongly favor raising taxes on the rich. Why are Democrats struggling to do so?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: A homeless encampment in Phoenix.

item.title: New Details of Trump Pressure on Justice Dept. Over Election
item.description: A Senate panel fleshed out how Donald Trump pursued his plan to install a loyalist as acting attorney general to pursue unfounded reports of fraud.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.media:description: Jeffrey Clark, who led the Justice Department�s civil division, was working with President Trump to devise ways to cast doubt on the election results.

item.title: Trump and Justice Dept. Lawyer Said to Have Plotted to Oust Acting AG
item.description: Trying to find another avenue to push his baseless election claims, Donald Trump considered installing a loyalist.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.media:description: Jeffrey Clark, who led the Justice Department�s civil division, had been working with President Donald Trump to devise ways to cast doubt on the election results.

item.title: Federal Judge Pauses Strict Texas Law Banning Most Abortions
item.description: A sharply worded ruling sided with the Justice Department, which sued to block the measure last month after the Supreme Court declined to intervene.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise and Katie Benner
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: An abortion rights rally at the Texas Capitol in Austin on Saturday. Since a new law took effect last month, women in Texas have scrambled to find abortion providers in other states.

item.title: The Afghan War: A Photographer�s Journal Since 2001
item.description: One of the first things the New York Times photographer Tyler Hicks witnessed after arriving in Afghanistan in late 2001, soon after U.S. airstrikes on Oct. 7 opened the invasion, was the execution of a wounded Taliban fighter. The scene shocked him, upending everything he thought he knew about war and about the Afghan Northern Alliance � the U.S.-aligned fighters who had been his guides and protectors, and the Talib�s killers.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Hicks and David Zucchino

item.title: C.I.A. Reorganization to Place New Focus on China
item.description: The agency will create two new mission centers, one focused on China, the other focused on emerging technology, climate change and global health.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: The reorganization of the C.I.A. is centered on the establishment of a new China mission center.

item.title: China�s Power Crunch Exposes Tensions Ahead of Key U.N. Climate Summit
item.description: Keeping global temperatures from dangerous levels means China must pivot away from coal immediately. Its soaring energy demand and rolling blackouts mean it probably won�t.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabri� for The New York Times
item.media:description: Construction on the Zhongtang gas-fired power plant in Dongguan, China, one of several new gas plants being built in the area to meet the country�s energy needs as it pivots from coal.

item.title: Which Climate Threats Are Most Worrisome? U.S. Agencies Made a List.

item.title: N.Y. Charter School Prepares Students for Basketball Careers

item.media:description: The school is named after Earl Monroe, who won an N.B.A. title with the Knicks in 1973 and is a school trustee.

item.title: Dodgers Will Face Giants in Division Series After Wild-Card Win

item.title: Kashmir Seeing Surge in Militant Attacks, Two Teachers Are the Latest Victims
item.description: The killings on Thursday were the latest in a series of attacks largely targeting Hindu and Sikh civilians in Kashmir, where tensions are high after India revoked the region�s autonomy two years ago.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Indian security forces standing guard after suspected militants killed two teachers at a school in Srinagar on Thursday.

item.title: Business Updates: Tesla Investors to Vote on Two Board Seats
item.description: Activist shareholders have submitted five proposals to compel Tesla to disclose more information about its efforts to diversify its work force, how it handles employee disputes and its human rights record.

item.title: Texas Man Is Sentenced to 15 Months for Online Covid-19 Hoax
item.description: Christopher Charles Perez, 40, wrote on Facebook last year that he had paid someone who was infected with the coronavirus to lick groceries at a San Antonio supermarket, federal prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: An H-E-B store in the Las Palmas neighborhood of San Antonio. Prosecutors said Christopher Charles Perez wrote on Facebook that items at another H-E-B store had been contaminated with the coronavirus.
